Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Story:
I stared at my phone, torn between two worlds. My little sister’s voice message was bubbling with excitement—she’d just landed her dream job, and tonight she wanted to celebrate with me, just the two of us, like we always promised. I could almost hear her smile, and I knew how much this moment meant to her. But as I listened, my phone buzzed again. It was my boyfriend, his texts heavy with grief. He’d lost his father unexpectedly, and he needed me—needed my comfort, my presence, my arms around him as he tried to make sense of the world’s cruelty.

My heart ached. My sister expected me to be her cheerleader, to show up and make her feel special, just as she’d done for me so many times before. But my boyfriend was lost, and I was the only person he wanted right now. I felt pulled apart, guilty for even considering letting either of them down. I paced my room, clutching my phone, wishing I could split myself in two. The weight of their needs pressed on me, and I didn’t know how to choose.
